reviewText: Viewed: 6/14Rate: 86/13: I remembered Fatso when it ran a lot on HBO during the late 80's. Sad to say, it's a film that I never saw but only to retain the knowledge of the title as a derisive label for the particular group. I finally got the chance to see it as a premiere on TCM recently. To my surprise, I found Fatso an entertaining picture which I classified as a nice slice of real life story. Dom Deluise was perfect for the role although I honestly never saw him as a fatso or even close to being fat. Just a bit of exercise, and he would have looked pretty good slimmed down. It's the supporting cast that made the film workable. One best performance out of the bunch was Ron Carey as Dominick's little brother. Anne Bancroft was a bit too much for me. Sad to say, Dom, Ron, and Anne had long passed away. Candice Azzara, who played Lydia, provided a nice sparkplug to provide the film a subplot to give the film another dimension. All in all, Fatso was the type of a low-key picture that succeeded mightily well with very low expectations; it sure showed.

reviewText: Others have mentioned how this movie depicts what it's really like to be part of an Italian family.  I could not agree more.  One scene that I particularly loved is when he is trying to tell his Aunt on the phone (who speaks and understands very little English) that his brother is studying.  He keeps repeating "Frankie's studying" and she doesn't understand.  Finally he gives up and says "Frankie's SLEEPING!"  I could not stop laughing.  It brought back memories of me trying to talk to my grandmother on the phone.

reviewText: I have seen this movie many times on TV and just purchased Dom's cookbook "Eat This, you'll feel better".  So anyway - after reading all the recipes and thinking about his (Dom's) personality - I just wanted to buy FATSO.Was SHOCKED at the price $89.00 !!!  Why?  What is the reason?I read the reviews and they were GREAT.  REALLY made me want the movie even more.  My husband is from Brooklyn and I'm from New Jersey.  They said it all - so true - this is a REAL Italian Family movie - so entertaining and makes you so hungry for the food.  I SO want a hot dog from the cart!!!!!  Live in Texas now and while they have great Mexican food - they do NOT know how to make a sub, Pizza or a sausage and peppers sandwich!!!!Guess I will just have to bite the bullet and pay $89.00 for this movie!!!!!  FATSO !!! - Funny - he was not even FAT in this movie - miss you Dom

reviewText: Recently caught this movie on HBO, and now it's definitely going into my DVD collection. Anne Bancroft's writing and direction are truly superb.Found it to be hold-my-sides funny, yet sincerely touching. I love the interaction between Dom DeLuise and Ron Carey as the two brothers, and it's great to see Ron Carey get much more to do here than his oftentimes brief appearances on Barney Miller as Officer Levitt.Candice Azzara as the love interest is perfectly cast opposite Dom DeLouise. The two of them made even my jaded heart remember what it feels like to fall head-over-heels in love!There are just so many funny, funny scenes in this movie. And so much quiet tenderness that really brings back the feeling of the pre-cellphone, pre-texting, pre-blogging days. Loved this movie!
summary: You don't have to be Italian to love this movie

reviewText: This movie is charming and I couldn't help but be entertained by Dom D.'s acting.  He plays a fat man (really he's not that fat in the movie, more like chubby) who struggles with his addiction to food.  He goes on a strict diet, but it only fuels his hunger until he falls in love.  Dom D. cries a lot in this movie and talks about food a lot.  He does a pretty good job of making you hungry.  I have to admit that while watching it I had cravings for donuts, cake and ice cream.  Dom D. makes the movie worth buying.
summary: I couldn't help but be entertained

reviewText: A potentially heartwarming family story that missed the mark with theexception of two scenes. The Brother's Happy Song and Dance, whichtruly portrayed the special relationship they had. I enjoyed those twomoments immensely.Otherwise, was unhappy with the mixed messages of take care of yourhealth but eat as much as you want and expect everyone to just acceptwho you are. Huh? I thought the entire premise of the film was thetragedy and ensuing trauma experienced by the family after Cousin Sal'searly demise.Dom's acting chops were clearly evident throughout. To be honest, whenI saw his name, I assumed endless scenes of mugs and pratfalls. He tookthis role very seriously and made you even think he was one of lafamilia.I found too many scenes with very limited or no dialogue and extendedshots that were overdone. I disliked the Chubby Checker choke out, toohammy but again with potential for poignancy. And how could his sisterbe skinny as a rail, with all those delicious treats and that gravylooked to die for.Listening to that list of foods not to eat, for an east coast Italian,that is remnant of a death sentence. But you learn to change over timeand treat yourself once in a blue moon. Perhaps not La Dolce Vita butPfizer et al. doesn't eat (lol) up your paycheck! The topic needs to beseriously addressed and remade for the current obesity crisis thatcontinually worsens. Mange but please no kale!

reviewText: I enjoyed Fatso as a child because of the physical comedy in the movie. I was a fan of Dom DeLuise early on. I consider his work in Fatso and The End to be his best work. Now that I'm older the movie appeals to me because of the story. It mostly is a story about over indulgence. How outside influences and (family) tradition can weigh heavy on an individual's life choices.Fatso, is a story of finding love regardless of ones flaws. Regardless of an individual's weaknesses it's often about their personality and character that leads to fulfilled love.I still find Fatso funny. However, for different reasons. The movie to me is a classic. It is inspiring, thought provoking and at times hilarious. Fatso was written and directed by, Anne Bancroft.

reviewText: FATSO (Writ./Prod./Dir. Anne Bancroft, 1980, 93 minutes) is a film I have loved since it was first released--and I love the late Anne Bancroft because she reminded me so much of my mother. This film, starring Dom DeLuise, was written and directed by Bancroft and it is sadly, unjustly forgotten.I was ruminating about Anne Bancroft, her husband Mel Brooks and how they started, how they became famous. It is interesting to note Anne Bancroft really first hit the public eye as a movie star, while Brooks was still a back-room TV sitcom writer. This led me to think about FATSO and how it invariably makes us all collapse with laughter whenever we see it.Dom plays Dominic DiNapoli (credited as "Dominick" and by the way DiNapoli was Bancroft's mother's maiden surname), a fun-loving, gentle Italian giant who loves to eat. He struggles with his weight and general unattractive qualities a laMarty--that is until he meets the woman of his dreams, Lydia (a hilarious Candice Azzara). The beauty is Lydia is half-Italian and Catholic...Dom couldn't have dreamed a better woman. Anne Bancroft has a lengthy cameo as Dom's harpy of a sister, Antoinette.This incredibly ahead-of-its-time comedy focuses on everything from sadness and cultural isolation to the weight-loss movement and sad loss of self-worth...and these are most definitely even more cogent now than they were in 1980. Bancroft and Mel Brooks always had a nose for the things that matter. As you enjoy the rich, emotional comedy of this great family film, do not forget that it clearly depicts real problems we face today.Dom's entanglement with a weight-loss program results in one of the most hysterical comedic sequences ever filmed. That good old 1970s TV bit player Ron Carey plays Dom's brother Frankie--their exchanges and witty dialogue proved Bancroft was every bit the equal of Oscar Wilde and even Jane Austen. So no, you cannot claim to be a film buff or true comedy fan if you have missed this film.Like Dom and his Chinese food, you'll find you cannot live without it. Best of all, it has a happy ending with a powerful message that I think everyone needs to learn.WARNING: Be alert, because at these prices I'm not really certain what you're getting. A new trade-in will net you $25 on a gift card, yet I saw a copy of this DVD for sale here for around $100. The present low price of $50 is the LOWEST on offer which probably means it is a used DVD--I'm not sure, but one thing of which I am certain is it shames me to see how greedy people are.
summary: Anne Bancroft's writing/directing tour-de-force, one of the greatest comedies ever made
Title: N/A

reviewText: 'Fatso' is unquestionably the most Italian movie out there.  What I mean is that when you watch this movie, you experience the many ways that Italians live, love, interact with family, and take part in the world.  There are so many parallels to real Italians it's uncanny.  Some examples:- The opening funeral scene with Dom's cousin Salvatore (just the names are enough!!)- The way in which food is used to calm down Dom as a young boy, and how he uses it to calm himself down as an adult- The family's life in New York- The relationship between Dom, his brother Frankie, and his sister AntoinetteThe movie is funny, sad, heartwarming, and so many other emotions.  The performances are outstanding.  First, there's the late great Dom Deluise playing a character which is, essentially, himself.  He is so realistic you feel you are truly watching Dominic DiNapoli and not the actor who is portraying him.  Then there's Ron Carey, who plays Dom's younger brother Frankie.  Carey does such a good job that you really think the two are brothers in real life.  Finally, there's the acting genius of the late Anne Bancroft.  She plays sister Antoinette to a 'T' in so many ways.  I especially was touched by how she showed both anger and love towards her brother and how her ranting and raving are such a memorable part of the movie.Besides the 'Italian angle', there are so many other great things in this movie, including the Chubby Checkers (hysterical), 'get the honey junior', the 'candle snuffer outer', and the romance between Dom and Lydia.  It just goes on and on!This is such a great movie in so many ways, you have to see it.  It may have not made too much of a splash when it was out, but it's surely one of the best, most realistic movies ever.  It's a favorite of mine and hopefully will become a favorite of yours.
summary: If You Want to Know What It's Like to Be Italian, Watch This Movie

reviewText: I absolutely love this movie--perhaps it's my predominantly Italian background.  "Fatso" is the closest a movie has ever gotten to what the urban Italian-American is like. I don't think a lot of folks will get the humor-it's of a very special brand.  This is the type of film where even the crudeness works for it.It's also one of a kind, since this was the first mainstream American film whose director and DOP were women.  Anne Bancroft shows her real talent here as Antoinette Fasano (DeLuise's sister)-a woman of intense emotion.  The storyline is a little thin but the acting and script are great, hilarious and first rate.

reviewText: This is a little treasure trove of a film. Superb actress, Anne Bancroft (aka Anna Maria Louise Italiano), only wrote one screenplay and only directed one movie -and this was it. She worked through her husband's production company (Brookfilms), and put together a precious commodity for the ages. It is a shame she never directed again. She had a terrific comic ear for dialogue, cast well, and must have done the project as a labor of love; perhaps too much so.. Her work was reminiscent of the writing and directing of Elaine May. But possibly the stress of being the matriarch and Madre for a giggling gaggle of comedic actors, and the go-to gal for everyone else did not turn out to be much "fun".She seemed to have a very slim budget to work with. She cast herself in the film, and did a wonderful acting job as the hysterically domineering sister, Anoinette. She ended up with a crew of mostly television veterans, and the result was the finished film looked like it was created "on the cheap". The rather pedestrian cinematography was done by TV veteran Brianne Murphy. The unremarkable musical score was composed by Joe Penzetti, a "B" film, and TV veteran. The strength of this film was in the writing and the acting--and of course the directing.Dom DeLuise played Dominick DiNapoli, a 40ish overweight bachelor, still living at home, a gourmet cook, and a champion calorie consumer. This was one of Dom's best roles, although admittedly it was not much of a stretch for him. His sensitive nature and his ability to weep on cue gave the character depth. Ron Carey played his brother, Frankie, and he gave it just the right blend of bathos, chaos, and burlesque. Candice Azzara played the lovely Lydia, Dom's love interest. Her Lydia was shy, lonely, struggling to be independent, very religious, creative, fussy, oddly realistic, idealistic, nave -and when asked if she still was a virgin, she replied, "Nearly." She reminded me some of Carol Kane with her nuanced and well thought out performance.There are those folks who might feel that this movie is lightweight, not on a par with Carl Reiner's manic WHERE'S PAPA? (1970), or Mel Brooks side-splitting THE PRODUCERS (1968), nor did it have the sweet sarcasm of A THOUSAND CLOWNS (1965). So as a New York based comedy it was overshadowed by the bigger box office and critical hits. Yet this gentle and touching film represents the genuine warmth and sentiment that was missing from the darker and more profane comedies. For Dom DeLuise fans, it is a must-see. For the rest of us it is a great time at the Bijou.
summary: To Eat, or Not to Eat

reviewText: This film has the wrong title. It's really not about fat people. It's about eating, dining, snacking, and then starting all over again. It has a wonderful food orgy sequence that's written so well it should have won an award. It's really a love story with over-eating as a backdrop. Lots of eating. Dom DeLuise is perfect in the role. Ron Carey, the "I got it" guy from HIGH ANXIETY is great. Mrs. Robinson should have stuck to her chores as director and let someone else play her part.Do not eat before you see this film.Do not eat after you see this film.Eat while you see this film.I had a chocolate fudge pudding cake stuffed with fresh bananas and topped with whipped cream and strawberries with a medium size scoop of pistachio ice cream. And a Diet Coke.

reviewText: I first saw this movie at age 16 in 1980, and boy does it still make melaugh whenever I've seen it throughout the years!I would argue this as one of the late Dom Deluise's greatest movie performances,alongside his stuff with Burt Reynolds in the 70's.I'm going to assume that most of you out there have already seenthis movie at least once, so I'm going to spare you a blow by blowfilled with spoilers, but suffices to say that this movie has plentyof good belly laughs in it! (-: The interplay between Dom & the actor who playshis baby brother, who he dotes over is one of the film's highlights.Anne Bancroft was priceless as the always irrate curmedgeonof a sister who doesn't know how to communicate her love other than to hit & scream!She also wrote & directed the whole film, which I didn't find out until years later!The whole ensemble cast was great in this.A classic addition to your DVD collection for all time!
summary: Obesity, Food Obsession, Desperate Measures, Love & Hilarity In A Brooklyn Italian-American Family!!

reviewText: Fatso! The title puts you on notice that there is nothing of a politically correct nature here. Prepare to squirm in your seat -- perhaps with recognition of yourself or members of your own family. There are no holds barred here, we see this amazing circle of friends and family "warts and all." They live large. They love large. They eat large, and therein lies the problem.The family makes you fat from when you are a little kid. You grow up and the society of the outside "real" world hates you for it. Your family wants you to lose weight now, too. But they feed you tons just the same.How do you survive? Can you ever find a soulmate other than a pepperoni pizza or a cheese cake?If you haven't seen this well-loved but little-known gem of a movie yet, please buy your copy of it now. It doesn't matter if you are Italian, Irish, or Indian. This is a movie about all families and the struggle we all undergo to live as best we can and be true to ourselves as individuals -- not just members of a group.If you don't absolutely adore Dom Deluise already, you will love him when you see this film.I can't recommend it highly enough. Fatso is a classic film.
summary: One of the funniest and most heartfelt comedies of all time!

reviewText: I've watched FATSO at least five times now, and every time, I'm hysterical from beginning to end!  My children, all teenagers, happened to hear me howling with laughter one evening, and came in to watch.  They were soon on  the floor, gasping for air.  There is nothing disappointing about this  movie, except that I would love to know what the characters are up to now!  I don't think Anne Bancroft got enough credit for her fine  directorial debut!  But that is common for movies directed by women; their  work is usually dismissed and under valued.
summary: Fatso: A Mardi Gras of Laughs!

reviewText: Anne Bancroft's slice of Italian life film is both funny and true to the ways of a middle class Italian family. From the close knit family ties to the pot of simmering gravy on the stove, it never hits a false note. The film is far more than a superficial comedy with equal amounts of drama and romance. Dom De Luise is perfect as a middle aged man who has been raised to use food as a comforting tool to ease his aching heart in times of sorrow.The film sports a great cast and some very funny scenes (i.e.. the fight between Dom and his brother with a kitchen knife is pure gold!), but has equally tender moments when Dom falls in love and he starts to lose weight without trying. I think the film also shows the absurdity of diets if not handled in a way that the dieter can live with over time. You can't take off a life time worth of fat in a short period of time and you will never keep it off if you don't allow yourself to eat the foods you love.This is a classic film that really hasn't be given it's due. It's a wonderful black comedy film that will make you laugh and has some insight on how hard it is for people who have a weight problem to stick to their diet program. The DVD is out of print and deserves a nice special edition.

reviewText: The Movie:Fatso!My review is brief; the film is a funny and sensitive, Black Comedic, satirical, Romantic, love story, focused on Italian America culture and food.The cast is mostly Italian, including the director. Dom Deluise is incredible and the Food Junky Splurge scene is at the same time both hilarious and sad. So if you are Italian American, or of any ethnic group which appreciates the food, the culture and humor of same, this is a hilarious and yet poignantly, sensitive, ethnic film classic.Ann Bancroft, is an Italian American, actor/director and is also related to the late, great, Oak Park Illinois architect; Frank Lloyd Wright.

reviewText: It's hard not to feel good after watching this very funny and basically warm hearted look at amiddle aged Italian man confronting his love for food that's been ingrained in his character since ealiest childhood. For anyone raised in an Italian-American family the characterizations will ring true. The main character played by Dom Delouise is not really that fat but his cousin's premature death inspires him to attempt to give up the foods he loves and the results are very funny. The film is really kind spirited and inoffensive despite the title.

reviewText: We can disregard Maltin on this one. This film is a true modern classic in which a man battles the temptation of food. He is a wonderful guy, outgoing, charming, warm,fat, who adores food. The scene in which he is  being told by the dietician the many, many items that he cannot eat has me  still laughing -- the tragic look on the poor fellow's face becomes sadder  and sadder as she rattles off the long list of delicious, but forbidden  delicacies. When Dom goes beserk in the night and threatens his baby  brother with a knife to get the key to the food cabinet, the brother calls  his dieters group "Chubby Checkers" for help. These two enormous  checkers rush over and proceed to talk about food, the things they love:  "have you ever sucked out the jelly in a jelly donut and filled it  with chocolate chip ice cream?" Needless to say, what follows is a  riot, both of food and comedy.Highly recommended if you have a warm  heart and maybe a less than perfect body.
